bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 6, 1876

div1.p: Reed visits a sick friend in Brooklyn. He was impressed with Baltimore on his trip home.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 6, 1876
div1.opener:
C1
B9
Willet's Point, N.Y.H.
March 6th 1876.
My own, little darling;
div1.p:
It is eve-
ning ere I begin my letter,
but you must not, on that
account, darling, suppose
that I have forgotten the
promise to write you
punctually, which I made
when I left. The reason I
did not write, this morning,
was due to the fact that, on
arriving, at the Point, I found
a letter from an acquain-
tance in Brooklyn, stating
that his wife was quite
sick & urgently requesting
me to call, at once. Although
much exhausted in body &
mind, I went down, as
soon as I had finished
my Breakfast & did not
return till after six o'clk
this evening. You can easily
imagine, at the present time,
that I do not feel very
much refreshed, after my ad-
ditional journey of to-day-
Still I cannot, nor will I
close my eyes without writ-
ing a few words to my own
little love. As I wrote you
on Saturday night, I did not
make connection at Baltimore
with the New York Train, and
hence had to spend the day
in Baltimore. I went to Bar-
num's Hotel & was agreeably
surprised to find that it
was a very elegant Hotel,
with a very enticing Bill
of Fare, to which I paid
my very best respects. I
took quite a jaunt over
the City before dinner &
was much more favorably
impressed with the extent
& beauty of the town than on any pre-
vious visit- Indeed, it is as
very much larger city than
I had supposed & has
some very pretty streets-
And much to my surprise,
in conversing with a gen-
tleman, who resides there, I
find that rents & expenses of living
are quite moderate. In fact
rents are very much cheap-
er than in the little town
of Norfolk- So that when
we do finally conclude to
resign our commissions
& tell “uncle Sam” goodbye,
we will certainly give the
preference to Baltimore-
After my walk, I found it
necessary to refresh myself
with sleep, as I had ob-
tained but very little during
my trip up the Bay- So, even
after retiring, it was long
before I could slumber, so
much was I thinking of you,
my own, sweet Emilie. And
when I did, at last, fall asleep,
I it was but to dream of
you. Oh! what would I not
give, this night, to see your
darling face! All, all that
I possess- Pardon this short
note, but I am so fatigued, I can
write no more- Will write again,
on Thursday.
